citations.narrative:
The records for offspring born of animals on the property and other acquisitions and dispositions of animals is incomplete.
There is no official record of animal births that have occurred at the facility that can be matched to sales invoices of
animals. Several dispositions of animals since the last inspection are missing (3 red foxes, 2 artic foxes, 3 chinchillas, and
a VA opossum). Additionally, there is acquisition paperwork on animals without corresponding dispositions. Not having
proper record keeping for the facilities does not allow for proper trace back of animals during a disease outbreak and does
not allow for proper accountability or identification of the animals during inspection. Correct by April 13, 2023 by ensuring
that records are kept and maintained which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each animal for which
has been purchased, or otherwise acquired, owned, held or otherwise disposed of, in their possession or under their
control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed. The records shall include any offspring born of
any animal while in their possession or under their control.

An indoor rabbit enclosure housing two adult rabbits has large amounts of rust flaking and peeling off the metal bars and
support structure. Large quantities of rust can compromise the structural integrity of the enclosure, create sharp edges
that can lead to animal injury, and prevent adequate cleaning and sanitation of the enclosures. Correct by April 10, 2023
by ensuring the housing facility for the indoor rabbits is structurally sound, maintained in good repair, and protects the
animals from injury.

The metal side wall of a barn shelter is bent and rusted along the bottom edge. The rust has caused the metal to
disintegrate, leaving sharp edges behind. Parts of the metal wall are bent, creating sharp edges of metal that protrude
away from the shelter and into the pasture. Sharp edges can injure animals housed on either side of the metal wall and
disintegrating metal quickly looses structural integrity. Correct by April 20, 2023 by ensuring all facilities are structurally
sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The records for offspring born of animals on the property and other acquisitions and dispositions of animals is incomplete. 
There is no official record of animal births that have occurred at the facility that can be matched to sales invoices of 
animals. Several dispositions of animals since the last inspection are missing (3 red foxes, 2 artic foxes, 3 chinchillas, and 
a VA opossum). Additionally, there is acquisition paperwork on animals without corresponding dispositions. Not having 
proper record keeping for the facilities does not allow for proper trace back of animals during a disease outbreak and does 
not allow for proper accountability or identification of the animals during inspection. Correct by April 13, 2023 by ensuring 
that records are kept and maintained which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each animal for which 
has been purchased, or otherwise acquired, owned, held or otherwise disposed of, in their possession or under their 
control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed. The records shall include any offspring born of 
any animal while in their possession or under their control. 
3.50(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An indoor rabbit enclosure housing two adult rabbits has large amounts of rust flaking and peeling off the metal bars and 
support structure. Large quantities of rust can compromise the structural integrity of the enclosure, create sharp edges 
that can lead to animal injury, and prevent adequate cleaning and sanitation of the enclosures. Correct by April 10, 2023 
by ensuring the housing facility for the indoor rabbits is structurally sound, maintained in good repair, and protects the 
animals from injury. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The metal side wall of a barn shelter is bent and rusted along the bottom edge. The rust has caused the metal to 
disintegrate, leaving sharp edges behind. Parts of the metal wall are bent, creating sharp edges of metal that protrude 
away from the shelter and into the pasture. Sharp edges can injure animals housed on either side of the metal wall and 
disintegrating metal quickly looses structural integrity. Correct by April 20, 2023 by ensuring all facilities are structurally 
sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
